description: A telescope is shown to introduce the concept of observing the moon. This sets the context for looking closely at how the moon's appearance changes.

object: The 8 Phases of the Moon (Linear Diagram)
description: An overview image displays all eight phases of the moon in a straight line. This provides a complete visual summary of the entire cycle that will be discussed.
This is the first phase. The visual is an empty black frame with an arrow pointing to the center, representing that the New Moon is not visible from Earth.
A conceptual diagram showing the Moon positioned between the Sun and the Earth. This illustrates why the New Moon is dark, as the sunlit side faces away from us.
The second phase. It shows a small sliver of the moon illuminated on the right side. 'Waxing' means the light is growing.
The third phase. It shows the moon as exactly half-lit on the right side. This marks one-quarter of the way through the full lunar cycle.
The fourth phase. It shows more than half of the moon illuminated on the right side, but it is not yet a full circle. It is still 'waxing' or growing towards a full moon.
The fifth phase. The entire circle of the moon is illuminated. This is the brightest phase and marks the end of the 'waxing' period.
The sixth phase. After being full, the light begins to shrink, or 'wane'. This phase shows a moon that is more than half-lit, but the illumination is on the left side.
The seventh phase. It shows the moon as exactly half-lit on the left side. This signifies that the moon is three-quarters of the way through its cycle.
The eighth and final phase before the New Moon. It shows a small sliver of the moon illuminated on the left side as the light continues to 'wane' or shrink.
All eight phases are shown arranged in a circle to represent the continuous, repeating monthly cycle of the moon, from New Moon and back again.
